awd_titl_txt: Fourth International Conference on Quantitative Ethnography (ICQE22)
awd_abstract_narration:
ECR's Building Capacity for STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) solicitation supports projects that build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality STEM education research that will enhance the nation's STEM education enterprise and broaden the pool of researchers that can conduct fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

Specifically, ECR: BCSER supports activities that enable early and mid-career researchers to acquire the requisite expertise and skills to conduct rigorous fundamental research in STEM education. ECR: BCSER seeks to fund research career development activities on topics that are relevant to qualitative and quantitative research methods and design, including the collection and analysis of new qualitative or quantitative data, secondary analyses using extant datasets, or meta-analyses.

This conference, to be held at the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus, will build the capacity of NSF-supported communities to benefit from the highly promising research methodology of quantitative ethnography (QE). This training workshop for young scholars, embedded in conference, supports the goals of the ECR program by developing a community of early career researchers to carefully use quantitative ethnography in the conduct of basic STEM education research. These scholars will be prepared to examine and empirically test new theory consistent with the central goals of the ECR program. The funding will support: a) attendance and training at an international conference on QE for doctoral and early career researchers to be held in the U.S., b) a technical immersion preconference workshop that several of participating researchers would lead for these young scholars, and c) a broader slate of symposium speakers who represent NSF supported disciplines that QE methods can benefit significantly.

The intellectual merit of the conference arises both from the appeal or promise of QE across numerous fields. The proposed activities are organized around broadening the impact of QE’s intellectual merit across new disciplines. The project maintains a consistent emphasis on furnishing next-generation researchers with conceptual and software tools and methodology to address important current and future questions across the spectrum of fields NSF supports in social sciences, basic STEM education research, and the learning sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System

por.por_cntn:
This project organized and supported the 4th International Conference on Quantitative Ethnography (ICQE22) took place from October 15th to 19th, 2022, at the University of Copenhagen in Copenhagen, Denmark.

 

Quantitative ethnography is a methodological approach and set of tools being used by more than 1000 researchers from 150 institutions across more than 30 countries. ICQE serves as a hub for this international community of researchers and practitioners who share a common objective: to produce meaningful analyses and interpretations of vast quantities of rich qualitative data. QE methodologies find application in an array of fields, including learning analytics, computer science, human factors engineering, psychology, sociology, and policy analysis. The conference supports the QE community by facilitating the exchange of ideas, resources, and inspiration for leveraging methodological innovations and applied research techniques that contribute to positive change in the world.

 

ICQE22 featured keynote addresses from two prominent QE scholars who explored novel combinations of QE tools and methods, as well as the evolving role of QE in longer-term research trajectories in fields where QE methods are still emerging. The conference also hosted an invited panel of experts who discussed the multifaceted role QE can play in policy studies, spanning four different domains: international development and policy analysis with UNESCO and the Liiv Center for Digital Anthropology, nursing education and policy in industry, learning analytics in education policy, and social service program evaluation.

 

Furthermore, the conference provided:

• Six workshops covering theoretical, methodological, and computational topics.

• A professional community development workshop designed to support junior scholars in navigating the job market, defining a research program, understanding the research funding landscape, and building collaborative partnerships.

• A doctoral consortium tailored for Ph.D. candidates embarking on their dissertation work using QE methods, with early-career advisors providing guidance.

 

For more information about the International Society for Quantitative Ethnography (ISQE), which hosts ICQE and other QE events, please visit the ISQE website.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/23/2023
Modified by: Brendan R Eagan
